abstract.p: Color Marketing Group, nonprofit association of 1,600 color designers, predicts 'spiritual, meditative' colors will be popular for manufactured goods in 2002, though high-technology products will favor bold colors (S)

block.p: Not taking chances with the fragile psyche of consumers, marketers will turn to soothing colors to sell their future goods, according to a group of color designers.

The Color Marketing Group, in Alexandria, Va., is a nonprofit association of 1,600 color designers that annually forecasts the hot new colors for manufactured products. The designers predict that spiritual, meditative hues will be the rage for 2002.
Not taking chances with the fragile psyche of consumers, marketers will turn to soothing colors to sell their future goods, according to a group of color designers.

The Color Marketing Group, in Alexandria, Va., is a nonprofit association of 1,600 color designers that annually forecasts the hot new colors for manufactured products. The designers predict that spiritual, meditative hues will be the rage for 2002.

With serene names like Calm Springs, ''the perfect blue influenced by sea and sky,'' to Bali, ''a brighter, clearer green-blue water color,'' these colors are bound to show up on cereal boxes or cars.

But not all products are expected to be mellow. Color Marketing thinks consumers looking for high-technology products will be willing to experiment with bold colors, like Mazenta, a new twist on magenta that ''leaps from retro right into the future.'' And if that doesn't grab them, there's Tangy, an ''adventurous, daring orange that rockets into space.''
